Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Calculus
Heavy quantitative analysis and real-world applications with calculus.
A deeper understanding of calculus and how to apply these things in different situations.
I learned how to critically think and how to further my skills of thinking critically.
I gained basic knowledge of calculus. I had already taken a calculus course in high school, but 110 & 111 were much more manageable/understandable.
I learned about the slicing method with integrals, but other than that it was review from work I did in high school.
Learnt about the actual definitions of mathematical terms such as integration and not just applications
The necessary calculus skills to help me succeed in this and subsequent classes
Basic Calculus and applications
A much better understanding of calculus and how it applies in real-life scenarios.
The learned trigonometry and the skills needed for integration.

It does what it says it's going to do. If you're taking MATH 111, you probably don't love math. This course is not going to change your mind but John Hall really tries to make it as painless as possible

Strengths: Great introductory course. Work-load was manageable and classes were engaging.
Cons: More in-class activities (handouts, group work, etc.)
More opportunity to get one on one meetings with the professors and more opportunity to get a more help with the material.

The strengths are that this class furthers my critical thinking skills, however this course is very challenging. What balances that out is that there are many opportunities to get tutors, go to office hours, as well as meet with professors. John Hall does an amazing job of making sure each student feels as though they have the proper help they needed.

I don't like math, nor am I good at it, but I felt that I was as engaged in the class as I personally could have been, and the structure of the class facilitated my learning experience. However, I do not think the weekly workshops should be mandatory.
Well taught, fair tests and good review. The daily quizzes were annoying at times though, I'd rather just have those as practice problems in class
weakness - had troubles understanding some of the theories as they seemed overcomplicated but got a firm grip once we started doing questions

This course has a good sense of support between students and ULA's as well as professors. I would like to examine some materials more closely. For example, we spend lots of time on the pure methodology for solving/deriving, but we breeze through the application problems, which are often more difficult to fully understand.
With the help of ULA office hours and professors, they provide a really strong support system and help you do well. The short quizzes every class period helped you gauge how you were doing.

The strengths of the class come from the professor and some of the ULAs. They were very passionate about making sure people understood the course material and passed the class. I could change the quizzes at the beginning of class because I feel like they don't much in terms of reviewing the previous classes materials and just stress people out. I would also change how the course ends with 2D and 3D density problems because it's something very difficult and needs to have more in-class time dedicated to it. Also, making it easier for people to see what their current grade in the course is, as opposed to just problem set average, would be a great help.
If you're just doing it for the QR credit, absolutely not. If you need some higher math for some courses you want to take, definitely.
Highly recommend for students looking for an intro into calculus. John Hall and Itziar do an incredible job of walking you through difficult concepts.
No. The better thing to do is take math 112.
Yes as long as they are willing to put in a lot of time and a lot of extra work in order to do well.
Yes. For a student who needs QR credits or needs math as a major requirement but doesn't like doing math, like me, I think this class is perfect.
Yes, it's well taught and theres a lot of support and help you can get.

With a previous knowledge of most of the topics the questions and application was relatively easy, however having to learn the theory of it made my understanding harder as I was unable to use the methods that I learnt in high school
Yes, as a student with a weak background in Calculus, this course taught me what I needed to know without me feeling as though I was falling behind.
Yes. It is a great course where you'll definitely pushed but will still feel very comfortable and ready for success!
It's a great introduction to calculus at Yale.
If somebody doesn't have a strong math background then yes.
